1.text:
Thank you for inviting me to be here this
morning to deliver the prestigious Charity

6.text:
Commission annual lecture. I am delighted
to have this opportunity to express my appreciation

14.text:
for all those who work in our charity sector
and for those who freely give their time,

20.text:
money and expertise in the service of others.
We are a country built on the bonds of family,

27.text:
community and citizenship and there is no
greater example of the strength of those bonds

32.text:
than our great movement of charities and social
enterprises. But the strength of that civil

38.text:
society – which I believe we should treasure
deeply – does not just depend on the ingenuity,

45.text:
generosity and commitment of countless volunteers,
social entrepreneurs and philanthropists.

51.text:
As with other parts of our economy, it also
depends on the practices that our charities

57.text:
and social enterprises adopt; and above all
on the public trust they command. That is

63.text:
why the work that William, Paula and their
team at the Charity Commission are doing is

68.text:
so important. Because the reforms they are
leading are strengthening the sector – and

74.text:
together with the new Fundraising Regulator
– ensuring public confidence in our charities

79.text:
and the contribution they make in helping
to meet some of the greatest social challenges

85.text:
of our time. And let’s be clear that some
of those challenges are significant and long-standing.

96.text:
We live in a country where if you’re born
poor, you will die on average 9 years earlier

101.text:
than others. If you’re black, you’re treated
more harshly by the criminal justice system

107.text:
than if you’re white. If you’re a white,
working-class boy, you’re less likely than

112.text:
anybody else in Britain to go to university.
If you’re at a state school, you’re less

118.text:
likely to reach the top professions than if
you’re educated privately. If you’re a

121.text:
woman, you’re likely to be paid less than
a man. If you suffer from mental health problems,

128.text:
there’s not enough help to hand. If you’re
young, you’ll find it harder than ever before

134.text:
to own your own home. There are not easy answers
to these problems, but it is vital that we

141.text:
come together to address them. For they are
all burning injustices that undermine the

147.text:
solidarity of our society and stunt our capacity
to build the stronger, fairer country that

153.text:
we want Britain to be. But the challenges
don’t end there. Governments have traditionally

160.text:
been good at identifying – if not always
addressing – such problems. However, the

166.text:
mission I have laid out for the government
– to make Britain a country that works for

170.text:
everyone and not just the privileged few – goes
further. It means more than fighting these

176.text:
obvious injustices. It means acknowledging
and addressing the everyday injustices that

183.text:
too many people feel too. Because while the
obvious injustices receive a lot of attention

189.text:
– with the language of social justice and
social mobility a staple of most politicians

195.text:
today – the everyday injustices are too
often overlooked. But if you’re from an

202.text:
ordinary working class family, life is much
harder than many people in Westminster realise.

207.text:
The injustice you feel may be less obvious,
but it burns inside you just the same. For

214.text:
you have a job but you don’t always have
job security. You have your own home, but

219.text:
you worry about paying the mortgage. You can
just about manage but you worry about the

223.text:
cost of living and getting your kids into
a good school. You are putting in long hours

228.text:
with little time for yourself – working
to live, and living to work. You give work

234.text:
your all, but there is still little left over
at the end of the month to spend on the things

238.text:
that really matter to you. Your wages have
stagnated for several years in a row, and

243.text:
you feel you are getting by, not necessarily
getting on. And at the same time, over recent

251.text:
years these people have felt locked out of
the political and social discourse in Britain.

257.text:
If they voiced their concerns, their views
were shut down. Decisions made in faraway

262.text:
places didn’t always seem to be the right
decisions for them. They saw their community

268.text:
changing, but didn’t remember being consulted
– or agreeing to – that change. They looked

273.text:
at the changing world – the onset of globalisation
and the advances in technology – and worried

279.text:
about what the future held for their children
and grandchildren. It is clear to me – and

286.text:
I believe that last year’s vote to leave
the European Union partially revealed this

290.text:
to be true – that there are growing numbers
of people in every part of our country – in

297.text:
our cities, suburbs, towns, countryside and
coastal areas – for whom this is the reality

302.text:
of life. And the consequence is this: when
you see others prospering while you are not;

310.text:
when you try to raise your concerns but they
fall on deaf ears; when you feel your very

314.text:
identity – all that you hold dear – is
under threat, resentments grow, and the divisions

321.text:
that we see around us – between a more prosperous
older generation and a struggling younger

326.text:
generation; between the wealth of London and
the rest of the country; between the rich,

331.text:
the successful and the powerful, and their
fellow citizens – become entrenched. That’s

337.text:
why I believe that – when we consider both
the obvious and the everyday injustices in

342.text:
unison – we see that the central challenge
of our times is to overcome division and bring

349.text:
our country together by ensuring everyone
has the chance to share in the wealth and

354.text:
opportunity on offer in Britain today. And
that starts by building something that I call

360.text:
the shared society. The shared society is
one that doesn’t just value our individual

365.text:
rights but focuses rather more on the responsibilities
we have to one another. It’s a society that

373.text:
respects the bonds that we share as a union
of people and nations. The bonds of family,

379.text:
community, citizenship and strong institutions.
And it’s a society that recognises the obligations

387.text:
we have as citizens – obligations that make
our society work. A few months ago at the

396.text:
Conservative Party Conference in Birmingham,
I upset some by saying that “if you think

402.text:
you’re a citizen of the world, you’re
a citizen of nowhere”. But my point was

407.text:
simple. It was that the very word ‘citizen’
implies that we have responsibilities to the

413.text:
people around us. The people in our community,
on our streets, in our places of work. And

420.text:
too often today, those responsibilities have
been forgotten as the cult of individualism

425.text:
has taken hold, and globalisation and the
democratisation of communications has encouraged

431.text:
people to look beyond their own communities
and immediate networks in the name of joining

436.text:
a broader global community. I want to be absolutely
clear about what I am saying here. I am not

444.text:
arguing against globalisation – nor the
benefits it brings – from modern travel

449.text:
and modern media to new products in our shops
and new opportunities for British companies

454.text:
to export their goods to millions of consumers
all around the world. Indeed, I have argued

460.text:
that Britain has an historic global opportunity
to lead the world in shaping the forces of

465.text:
globalisation so that everyone shares in the
benefits of economic growth. But just as we

474.text:
need to act to address the economic inequalities
that have emerged in recent years, so we also

480.text:
need to recognise the way that a more global
and individualistic world can sometimes loosen

485.text:
the ties that bind our society together, leaving
some people feeling locked out and left behind.

492.text:
And the central tenet of my belief – the
thing that shapes my approach – is that

498.text:
there is more to life than individualism and
self-interest. We form families, communities,

504.text:
towns, cities, counties and nations. And we
embrace the responsibilities those institutions

510.text:
imply. And government has a clear role to
play to support this conception of society.

518.text:
It is to act to encourage and nurture those
relationships, networks and institutions where

524.text:
it can. And it is to step up to correct injustices
and tackle unfairness at every turn – because

532.text:
injustice and unfairness are the things that
drive us apart. This means a government rooted

540.text:
not in the laissez-faire liberalism that leaves
people to get by on their own, but rather

545.text:
in a new philosophy that means government
stepping up – not just in the traditional

550.text:
way of providing a welfare state to support
the most vulnerable, as vital as that will

556.text:
always be. But actually in going further to
help those who have been ignored by government

561.text:
for too long because they don’t fall into
the income bracket that makes them qualify

565.text:
for welfare support. It means making a significant
shift in the way that government works in

571.text:
Britain. Because government and politicians
have for years talked the language of social

577.text:
justice – where we help the very poorest
– and social mobility – where we help

583.text:
the brightest among the poor. But to deliver
the change we need and build that shared society,

589.text:
we must move beyond this agenda and deliver
real social reform across every layer of society

595.text:
so that those who feel that the system is
stacked against them – those just above

600.text:
the threshold that attracts the government’s
focus today yet who are by no means rich or

604.text:
well off – are also given the help they
need. So we will recalibrate how we approach

612.text:
policy development to ensure that everything
we do as government helps to give those who

617.text:
are just getting by a fair chance – while
still helping those who are most disadvantaged.

624.text:
Because people who are just managing, just
getting by, don’t need a government that

628.text:
will get out of the way, they need a government
that will make the system work for them. An

633.text:
active government that will help them share
in the growing prosperity of post-Brexit Britain.

640.text:
That’s why we will shortly launch a new
housing white paper to boost supply, tackle

647.text:
the increasing lack of affordability, and
so help ordinary working people with the high

652.text:
costs of this most basic of necessities. It’s
why we will shortly publish a green paper

659.text:
to put forward our approach for a modern industrial
strategy, setting out our plans to encourage

665.text:
growth, innovation and investment and ensure
that as we aim to increase our overall prosperity

671.text:
– that prosperity is shared by people in
every corner of our country. It’s why as

677.text:
part of building a great meritocracy I have
already outlined plans to increase the number

682.text:
of good school places so that every child
– not just those who are fortunate to have

687.text:
parents who can afford to move to a good catchment
area or pay to go private – can enjoy a

693.text:
school place that caters to their individual
interests, abilities and needs. So with all

700.text:
these steps we will deliver this new agenda
of social reform. And government will step

706.text:
up to support and – where necessary – enforce
the responsibilities we have to each other

712.text:
as citizens, so that we respect the bonds
and obligations that make our society work.

720.text:
This means government supporting free markets
as the basis for our prosperity, but stepping

726.text:
in to repair them when they aren’t working
as they should. It means standing up for business

731.text:
as a great driver of prosperity and progress,
but taking action when a minority of businesses

738.text:
and business figures tear away at the social
contract between business and society by working

744.text:
to a different set of rules from everyone
else. It means creating an environment in

750.text:
which our charities and social enterprises
can thrive – but responding when a small

755.text:
minority pursue inappropriate and unacceptable
fundraising practices. And it means not being

762.text:
ambivalent about the efforts of all those
who give their time, money and expertise in

769.text:
the service of others; but recognising, supporting
and championing those who lead the way in

775.text:
shaping a civil society that can bring the
talents of so many in our voluntary sector

781.text:
to bear on some of the great social challenges
that we face together. That is why I have

786.text:
continued the important work that David Cameron
began through the Points of Light programme,

792.text:
using the office of Prime Minister every day
to recognise an outstanding volunteer in Britain

798.text:
whose service can be an inspiration to us
all. It is why we are making National Citizen

803.text:
Service a rite of passage for every young
person in Britain and supporting all those

808.text:
brilliant organisations in the Prince of Wales’
#iwill campaign who are encouraging our young

813.text:
people to give their time in the service of
others. And it is why we will continue to

818.text:
lead the way internationally in the development
of social finance to harness the full potential

824.text:
of our charities and social enterprises in
working with business and government to tackle

830.text:
some of the biggest social challenges in our
country. This is the new approach – the

839.text:
new philosophy – that we need in Britain
today. An approach with fairness and solidarity

845.text:
at its heart. And as we reflect on – and
implement – the result of the referendum,

851.text:
we must recognise that we have a unique opportunity
and responsibility to deliver the change that

858.text:
people need. An opportunity because Britain
is going through a period of great national

865.text:
change, and as we do so we have a once-in-a-generation
chance to step back and ask ourselves what

874.text:
kind of country we want to be. A responsibility
because a failure to take this opportunity

882.text:
to show the ability of mainstream, centre-ground
politics to respond to public concern would

889.text:
further entrench the very divisions we seek
to overcome. For we know what happens when

895.text:
mainstream, centre-ground politics fails.
People embrace the fringe – the politics

902.text:
of division and despair. They turn to those
who offer easy answers – who claim to understand

908.text:
people’s problems and always know what – and
who – to blame. We see those fringe voices

915.text:
gaining prominence in some countries across
Europe today – voices from the hard-left

920.text:
and the far-right stepping forward and sensing
that this is their time. But they stand on

926.text:
the shoulders of mainstream politicians who
have allowed unfairness and division to grow

931.text:
by ignoring the legitimate concerns of ordinary
people for too long. Politicians who embraced

938.text:
the twin pillars of liberalism and globalisation
as the great forces for good that they are,

944.text:
but failed to understand that for too many
people – particularly those on modest to

949.text:
low incomes living in rich countries like
our own – those forces are something to

954.text:
be concerned, not thrilled, about. Politicians
who supported and promoted an economic system

961.text:
that works well for a privileged few, but
failed to ensure that the prosperity generated

967.text:
by free markets and free trade is shared by
everyone, in every corner and community of

972.text:
their land. Politicians who made the deals
and signed the agreements that changed the

978.text:
nature of their country, but failed to listen
to the public’s concerns – dismissing

983.text:
them as somehow parochial or illegitimate
instead. The result of this consensus – this

992.text:
way of conducting politics – has been to
bring us to a place where all the old certainties

997.text:
are called into question. People are questioning
whether the system of globalisation, free

1003.text:
markets and free trade – one that has underpinned
so much of our prosperity – is actually

1009.text:
working for them. When they lose their jobs,
or their wages stagnate, or their dreams such

1015.text:
as owning a home seem out of reach, they feel
it is even working against them – serving

1020.text:
not their interests or ambitions, but those
of a privileged few. And they are questioning

1026.text:
the legitimacy of all the old institutions
and systems we have relied on for decades.

1033.text:
They have seen a small minority in the banking
and business sectors appearing to game the

1037.text:
system and play by their own rules. They have
watched Parliament dragged into a row about

1042.text:
political expenses, the media mired in questions
about phone-hacking, a system that allows

1048.text:
lawyers to get rich by hounding our brave
troops. And they come to a simple conclusion:

1055.text:
that there is one rule for the rich and powerful
and another for everyone else. This is dangerous

1062.text:
for it sows division and despair as the gap
between those who are prospering and those

1068.text:
who are not gets ever larger, and resentments
grow. And it emboldens the voices of protectionism

1075.text:
and isolation who would tear down all we have
achieved and take us back to the past. So

1082.text:
our responsibility is great. It is to show
that mainstream, centre-ground politics can

1088.text:
deliver the change people need. That mainstream,
centre-ground politics can respond to public

1094.text:
concern. And that a mainstream, centre-ground
government understands what needs to change

1100.text:
and has a plan to set things right. And that’s
why this government has a plan, not simply

1108.text:
to manage our withdrawal from the European
Union, but to take this opportunity to fundamentally

1114.text:
change Britain for the better. A comprehensive,
wide-ranging plan for the kind of country

1121.text:
we want to be. A plan to build a country where
wealth and opportunity are shared; where all

1127.text:
of us, no matter what our background, play
by the same rules; and where future generations

1133.text:
enjoy the same opportunities from which their
parents have benefited throughout their lives.

1139.text:
I will say more about this plan in the coming
weeks. I will talk more about our plans for

1143.text:
economic reform, our plans to build a global
Britain and our ambitions to build a more

1148.text:
united country. But at the heart of the plan
is a commitment to building a fairer society

1155.text:
and tackling the burning injustices that have
been allowed to stand for too long. And I

1162.text:
want to turn to one of those burning injustices
in particular – the burning injustice of

1169.text:
mental health and inadequate treatment that
demands a new approach from government and

1174.text:
society as a whole. Let me be clear: mental
health problems affect people of all ages

1181.text:
and all backgrounds. An estimated 1 in 4 of
us has a common mental disorder at any one

1188.text:
time. The economic and social cost of mental
illness is £105 billion – roughly the same

1195.text:
as we spend on the NHS in its entirety. And
for children – 1 in 10 of whom has a diagnosable

1203.text:
condition – the long term effects can be
crippling: children with behavioural disorders

1209.text:
are 4 times more likely to be drug dependent,
6 times more likely to die before the age

1215.text:
of 30, and 20 times more likely to end up
in prison. We all know someone – a family

1224.text:
member, friend or colleague – who is directly
affected by mental health problems. But while

1231.text:
people talk about ‘parity of esteem’ – and
it was a Conservative-led government that

1236.text:
legislated for it – there is no escaping
the fact that people with mental health problems

1242.text:
are still not treated the same as if they
have a physical ailment – or the fact that

1247.text:
all of us – government, employers, schools,
charities – need to do more to support all

1252.text:
of our mental wellbeing. As Home Secretary
I was determined to take on the grave injustices

1259.text:
concerning mental illness that were within
my remit – and I made improving the police

1264.text:
response to people with mental health needs
a top priority. And I am delighted that we

1269.text:
have taken great strides forward in reducing
the number of people suffering a mental health

1274.text:
crisis who end up in a police cell, for want
of somewhere else to go. Since 2011 to 2012,

1281.text:
there has been an almost 80% reduction of
such incidences across England – so more

1287.text:
people detained under section 136 of the Mental
Health Act are rightly being taken to a health-based

1293.text:
place of safety, rather than being held in
a cell. And for children and young people

1299.text:
the reduction is comparable, and through the
Policing and Crime Bill I personally introduced,

1304.text:
this practice will be abolished entirely for
under 18s from this spring. This proves that

1309.text:
innovative reforms that challenge the established
way of doing things can improve the response

1315.text:
to mental illness. Now as Prime Minister I
want us to go further. I want us to employ

1321.text:
the power of government as a force for good
to transform the way we deal with mental health

1326.text:
problems right across society, and at every
stage of life. For years the only people who

1333.text:
have stood up for those with mental ill health
have been civil society groups and charities.

1337.text:
Now I want us to build upon your success and
the fantastic work that many including those

1342.text:
here today are doing. Organisations such as
Mind who have led the way in helping those

1348.text:
experiencing mental health problems. The Heads
Together campaign – and the fantastic leadership

1353.text:
shown by their Royal Highnesses the Duke and
Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry – that

1358.text:
aims to break the stigma surrounding mental
health problems. And the tremendous campaigning

1364.text:
work by Black Mental Health UK – with whom
I worked at the Home Office – to expose

1370.text:
injustices in the way black people with mental
ill health in particular are treated, and

1376.text:
ensure politicians take action to put things
right. So you are leading the way – but

1383.text:
today I want us to forge a new approach recognising
our responsibility to each other, and make

1389.text:
mental illness an everyday concern for all
of us and in every one of our institutions.

1395.text:
What I am announcing are the first steps in
our plan to transform the way we deal with

1399.text:
mental health problems at every stage of a
person’s life: not in our hospitals, but

1404.text:
in our classrooms, at work and in our communities.
This starts with ensuring that children and

1411.text:
teenagers get the help and support they need
and deserve – because we know that mental

1416.text:
illness too often starts in childhood and
that when left untreated, it can blight lives,

1422.text:
and become entrenched. There is, for example,
evidence to suggest an increase in self-harm

1428.text:
among young people, with the number of 16-
to 24-year-old women reporting self-harm increasing

1435.text:
threefold – to 1 in 5 – between 2000 and
2014. And we know that the use of social media

1443.text:
brings additional concerns and challenges.
In 2014, just over 1 in 10 young people said

1449.text:
that they had experienced cyberbullying by
phone or over the internet. So first, we will

1455.text:
introduce a package of measures to transform
the way we respond to mental illness in young

1459.text:
people starting in our schools. We will pilot
new approaches such as offering mental health

1466.text:
first aid training for teachers and staff
to help them identify and assist children

1470.text:
experiencing mental health problems. And we
will trial approaches to ensure schools and

1475.text:
colleges work closer together with local NHS
services to provide dedicated children and

1481.text:
young people’s mental health services. These
steps will accompany a major thematic review

1486.text:
– led by the Care Quality Commission with
input from Ofsted – looking at services

1492.text:
for children and teenagers across the country
to find out what is working, and what is not.

1498.text:
Following this, CQC and Ofsted will consider
how their future joint programme of inspections

1504.text:
can ensure child and adolescent mental health
services are properly held to account for

1509.text:
performance. And alongside these reviews,
later this year we will bring forward a new

1515.text:
green paper on children and young people’s
mental health to transform services in education

1520.text:
and for families. These measures will build
on the work we are already doing to put a

1525.text:
stop to the untold misery of hundreds of children
being sent halfway across the country to access

1531.text:
mental health services. By 2021, no child
will be sent away from their local area to

1537.text:
be treated for a general mental health condition.
But treatment is only part of the answer.

1543.text:
We must look at what more can be done to prevent
mental health problems, and work with you

1549.text:
to capitalise on the crucial role civil society
has to play in helping young people – and

1554.text:
indeed people of all ages – build resilience.
Second, I want us to do more to support mental

1562.text:
wellbeing in the workplace. So I have asked
Lord Stevenson, who has campaigned on these

1567.text:
issues for many years, and Paul Farmer, CEO
of Mind and Chair of the NHS Mental Health

1572.text:
Taskforce, to work with leading employers
and mental health groups to create a new partnership

1578.text:
with industry, and make prevention and breaking
the stigma top priorities for employers. Because

1586.text:
mental wellbeing doesn’t just improve the
health of employees, it improves their motivation,

1592.text:
reduces their absence and drives better productivity
too. We will also review employment discrimination

1598.text:
laws for employees with mental health problems
to ensure they are properly supported. And

1604.text:
we will do everything we can to get the right
support to those with mental health problems

1609.text:
who are out of work. For example, through
our global leadership on social impact bonds

1615.text:
– which drive investment in social outcomes
– we are already providing up to £50 million

1621.text:
to support those with mental health issues
back into work and to help local areas tackle

1626.text:
the link between drug and alcohol dependency
and co-existing mental health problems. Third,

1637.text:
I want to ensure more people get the support
they need, when they need it, in their communities.

1642.text:
So we will make up to £15 million of extra
funding available for community clinics, crisis

1647.text:
cafes, and alternative places of safety to
support a wider range of preventative services

1652.text:
in the community, and ensure that charities,
churches and community organisations can access

1658.text:
funding to run them too. And we are already
investing over £10 million to support the

1663.text:
fast track Think Ahead programme – which
aims to increase the number of high-calibre

1668.text:
mental health social workers – by at least
300. Fourth, we will rapidly expand the treatment

1675.text:
available by investing £67.7 million in digital
mental health services. Online therapy has

1683.text:
the potential to transform the way mental
health services are delivered by allowing

1688.text:
people to check their symptoms, be triaged
online and receive clinically-assisted therapy

1693.text:
over the internet much more quickly and easily,
assuming it is clinically appropriate. These

1699.text:
treatments have been tested in other countries
and they work. In the right cases, they can

1705.text:
offer access to treatment far quicker than
traditional services. Fifth, we will right

1712.text:
the everyday injustices that those with mental
illness encounter – starting by examining

1718.text:
GP forms relating to mental health and debt.
Because sometimes those whose illness has

1723.text:
resulted in debt, or means they are struggling
to pay their debt, have to prove their mental

1729.text:
ill-health to debt collectors and pay their
GP to fill in a form to do so. Such a process

1735.text:
can worsen both mental illness and financial
difficulties, so we will work with the Money

1740.text:
and Mental Health Policy Institute to consult
on these forms, with a view to ending the

1745.text:
practice. And finally, today we are publishing
a strengthened cross-government suicide prevention

1754.text:
strategy, which sets out a comprehensive plan
to reduce the suicide rate in this Parliament,

1761.text:
and targets those most at risk such as young
and middle-aged men, those in contact with

1766.text:
the criminal justice system and those in the
care of mental health services. Because, on

1771.text:
average, 13 people kill themselves every day
in England, and if we want to improve the

1778.text:
life chances of current and future generations,
we need to address this shocking reality.

1785.text:
And in addition to all this we will ensure
that the NHS itself takes the steps it needs

1790.text:
to ensure that parity means just that: parity.
We will hold the NHS leadership to account

1797.text:
for the extra £1 billion we invested in mental
health last year. We will make sure that mental

1802.text:
illness gets the attention it deserves, in
funding, research and technology investment.

1807.text:
And we will be clear that when NHS leaders
are redesigning services and developing new

1811.text:
local solutions, mental health should get
its full weighting. As I have said these are

1817.text:
just the first steps in our plan to transform
our approach to mental health in this country.

1822.text:
Meeting this challenge will take years and
require more than government action alone

1826.text:
– it will need a sustained effort on the
part of everyone in this room and everyone

1832.text:
across society. But this is a historic opportunity
to right a wrong, and give people deserving

1840.text:
of compassion and support the attention and
treatment they deserve. And for all of us

1845.text:
to change the way we view mental illness so
that striving to improve mental wellbeing

1851.text:
is seen as just as natural, positive and good
as striving to improve our physical wellbeing.

1858.text:
For too long, mental illness has been something
of a hidden injustice in our country, shrouded

1864.text:
in a completely unacceptable stigma and dangerously
disregarded as a secondary issue to physical

1870.text:
health. Yet left unaddressed, it destroys
lives, separates people from each other and

1876.text:
deepens the divisions within our society.
Changing this goes right to the heart of our

1883.text:
humanity; to the heart of the kind of country
we are, the attitudes we hold and the values

1888.text:
we share. I remember the reaction when, back
in 2012, Charles Walker and Kevan Jones spoke

1897.text:
in Parliament about their own personal challenges
with mental illness. The courage of these

1903.text:
2 MPs – Conservative and Labour – to speak
out in this way, encouraged us all to put

1910.text:
aside party differences and come together
in solidarity.

1915.text:
That sense of solidarity will be essential
in helping us to transform the support we

1919.text:
offer those with mental health conditions
and to defeat the stigma that makes addressing

1925.text:
this issue so much harder than it should be.
But I also believe that in a wider sense,

1932.text:
that commitment to strengthening the bonds
we share as a union of people, can be a defining

1937.text:
part of how we meet the great challenge of
our time and bring our whole country together.

1944.text:
It is by tackling the injustice and unfairness
that drives us apart and by nurturing the

1950.text:
responsibilities of citizenship that we can
build that shared society – and make it

1955.text:
the bedrock of a stronger and fairer Britain
that truly does work for everyone.
